Emergency Medical Services for Children Reauthorization Act of 2024
To amend the Public Health Service Act to reauthorize the Emergency Medical Services for Children program.

action.text: Referred to the House Committee on Energy and Commerce.
Referred to the Subcommittee on Health.
Subcommittee Consideration and Mark-up Session Held
Forwarded by Subcommittee to Full Committee by the Yeas and Nays: 23 - 0.
Committee Consideration and Mark-up Session Held
Ordered to be Reported by the Yeas and Nays: 48 - 0.
Reported by the Committee on Energy and Commerce. H. Rept. 118-488.

calendar.text: Placed on the Union Calendar, Calendar No. 404.

action.text: Mr. Bucshon moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill.
Considered under suspension of the rules.
DEBATE - The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 6960.

At the conclusion of debate, the Yeas and Nays were demanded and ordered. Pursuant to the provisions of clause 8, rule XX, the Chair announced that further proceedings on the motion would be postponed.

vote.text: On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: (2/3 required): 399 - 13 (Roll no. 208).

action.text: Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
Received in the Senate and Read twice and referred to the Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions.
Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions discharged by Unanimous Consent.

vote.text: Passed Senate without amendment by Unanimous Consent.

action.text: Message on Senate action sent to the House.

committee.name: Senate Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions
House Energy and Commerce
committee.activity: Reported By, Markup By, Referred To

term.name: Emergency medical services and trauma care

bill.summary:
Emergency Medical Services for Children Reauthorization Act of 2024
This act reauthorizes through FY2029 the Emergency Medical Services for Children State Partnership Program, which is administered by the Health Resources and Services Administration. The program awards grants to state governments and medical schools to support emergency medical services for children who need treatment for trauma or critical care.
